name: CareConnect-ITK-Header-Practitioner-1
description: This profile carries details of the practitioner for which the information in the payload should be directed to.

element.short: A person with a formal responsibility in the provisioning of healthcare or related services
element.definition: A person who is directly or indirectly involved in the provisioning of healthcare.
element.comment: Note that a cab driver no longer fits the bill. You probably would be interested in the organization rather than the individual?

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain any narrative
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.definition: An identifier that applies to this person in this role.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the agent.

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment:
This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage. 

Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_resource_identifier
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

example.label: General
example.valueUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the Identifier.value itself is a full uri

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](extension-rendered-value.html).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)
II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Whether this practitioner's record is in active use
element.definition: Whether this practitioner's record is in active use.
element.comment: Default is true. If the practitioner is not in use by one organization, then it should mark the period on the PractitonerRole with an end date (even if they are active) as they may be active in another role.
element.requirements: Need to be able to mark a practitioner record as not to be used because it was created in error.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The name(s) associated with the practitioner
element.definition: The name(s) associated with the practitioner.
element.comment: The selection of the use property should ensure that there is a single usual name specified, and others use the nickname (alias), old, or other values as appropriate.In general select the value to be used in the ResourceReference.display based on this:1. There is more than 1 name2. Use = usual3. Period is current to the date of the usage4. Use = official5. Other order as decided by internal business rules.
element.requirements: The name(s) that a Practitioner is known by. Where there are multiple, the name that the practitioner is usually known as should be used in the display.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The use of a human name

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: A full text representation of the name.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Family name (often called 'Surname')
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name.  Not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.orderMeaning: Prefixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.orderMeaning: Suffixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.short: A contact detail for the practitioner (that apply to all roles)
element.definition: A contact detail for the practitioner, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
element.comment: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identificationThese typically will have home numbers, or mobile numbers that are not role specific.
element.requirements: Need to know how to reach a practitioner independent to any roles the practitioner may have.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A system is required if a value is provided.

element.short: Address(es) of the practitioner that are not role specific (typically home address)
element.definition: Address(es) of the practitioner that are not role specific (typically home address). Work addresses are not typically entered in this property as they are usually role dependent.
element.comment: The PractitionerRole does not have an address value on it, as it is expected that the location property be used for this purpose (which has an address).
element.requirements: The home/mailing address of the practitioner is often required for employee administration purposes, and also for some rostering services where the start point (practitioners home) can be used in calculations.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: postal | physical | both
element.definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of an address (physical / postal)

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc.
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.
element.orderMeaning: The order in which lines should appear in an address label

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: District name (aka county)
element.definition: The name of the administrative area (county).
element.comment: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' is used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abbreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Country (e.g. can be ISO 3166 2 or 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comment: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.short: male | female | other | unknown
element.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes.

element.short: The date on which the practitioner was born
element.definition: The date of birth for the practitioner.
element.requirements: Needed for identification.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Image of the person
element.definition: Image of the person.
element.comment: When providing a summary view (for example with Observation.value[x]) Attachment should be represented with a brief display text such as "Attachment".
element.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of patients and personnel. Fits with newer social media usage too.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
It the Attachment has data, it SHALL have a contentType

element.short: Qualifications obtained by training and certification
element.definition: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: xml:id (or equivalent in JSON)
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional Content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: An identifier for this qualification for the practitioner
element.definition: An identifier that applies to this person's qualification in this role.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the qualification.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)

II - see see identifier pattern at http://wiki.hl7.org/index.php?title=Common_Design_Patterns#Identifier_Pattern for relevant discussion. The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs.  Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]

element.short: Coded representation of the qualification
element.definition: Coded representation of the qualification.
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Specific qualification the practitioner has to provide a service

element.short: Period during which the qualification is valid
element.definition: Period during which the qualification is valid.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.
element.requirements: Qualifications are often for a limited period of time, and can be revoked.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If present, start SHALL have a lower value than end

mapping.map: IVL<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"] or URG<TS>[lowClosed="true" and highClosed="true"]

element.short: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification
element.definition: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification.
element.comment: References SHALL be a reference to an actual FHIR resource, and SHALL be resolveable (allowing for access control, temporary unavailability, etc). Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.short: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication
element.definition: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication.
element.comment: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
element.requirements: Knowing which language a practitioner speaks can help in facilitating communication with patients.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A person with a formal responsibility in the provisioning of healthcare or related services
NHS communication preferences for a resource
element.definition: Communication preferences including a list of Languages which may be used for communication

element.short: The SDS identifier that uniquely identifies the person
element.definition: The SDS identifier that uniquely identifies the person.

element.short: The SDS identifier that uniquely identifies the role profile of the person
element.definition: The SDS identifier that uniquely identifies the role profile of the person.

element.short: The date on which the practitioner was born
